item.title: Split Fiction Is Now EA's Second Most Played Game on Steam
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/split-fiction-ea-second-most-played-game-steam

EA and Hazelight Studios' latest release Split Fiction has already climbed its way through the publisher's Steam charts, and the co-op action-adventure game is now the second most-played EA game on the platform.

Per SteamDB, Split Fiction's 24-hour Steam player peak sits at 197,434, which is pretty impressive; it's more than double what predecessor It Takes Two achieved, and that game was phenomenally successful in sales terms.

The figure puts Split Fiction in second place, and while that's certainly an achievement Hazelight and Josef Fares can celebrate, I don't think the game has a hope of beating the first-place record holder given that it's battle royale FPS Apex Legends.

It is worth noting that since Split Fiction's Friend Pass allows players to enjoy the game with a friend even if they didn't buy it themselves, the Steam numbers don't necessarily translate into hard sales.

Still, the same is true of It Takes Two, so it's still a fair point of comparison in my books. It's fair to say that EA and Hazelight have a hit on their hands with Split Fiction, and I wouldn't be surprised if the numbers climb even higher over the weekend.

If you're not familiar with Split Fiction, it's the latest game from A Way Out and It Takes Two developer Hazelight Studios, headed up by industry iconoclast and noted Oscars hater Josef Fares.

The game sees you and a friend (it doesn't support single-player, much like the aforementioned games) playing as Mio and Zoe, two writers who find themselves sucked into the worlds they've created and looking for a way out.

Much like It Takes Two, Split Fiction features a variety of co-op-focused activities, including platforming, combat, and various wacky setpieces. It's pretty much exactly what you'd expect from a Hazelight game, it seems to me.

Split Fiction is available now for PC, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series X|S. You can check out our Erren's review of the game here, and be sure to check out her interview with Fares about the game as well.

item.title: Killing Floor 3 Delayed, Now Arriving Sometime Later This Year
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/killing-floor-3-delayed-2025

Tripwire Interactive has announced that upcoming multiplayer-focused zombie shooter Killing Floor 3 has been delayed, and the game has no new specific release date.

In a message on Steam, Tripwire says the decision to delay the game was made following feedback it received from a recent closed beta period. That feedback made Tripwire realize it had "missed the mark" with regards to Killing Floor 3.

According to Tripwire, the delay will afford the development team time to address some of the most pressing issues raised during the closed beta, including "performance/stability, UI/UX, lighting, and weapon feel". Those are some pretty fundamental issues.

Tripwire goes on to say that it has the "full support" of its parent company Embracer Group when it comes to addressing these issues, which will come as a relief given that the game was listed as one of the cornerstones of Embracer's 2025 lineup.

The developer says it doesn't know which of these issues will be fixed by the time of Killing Floor 3's launch, but that an update which will let you select your perk class and character independently "is planned for post-release".

The studio closes by saying that it intends to show "a more polished version of Killing Floor 3" later down the line, and that more information is coming "when [Tripwire is] ready to share more details".

This is where I'd normally trot out that misattributed Miyamoto quote about a rushed game being bad and a delayed game being good, but given that Tripwire doesn't seem to be able to promise all of the aforementioned issues will be fixed by launch, I'm not sure it's appropriate here.

In case you need a reminder, Killing Floor 3 is the third major installment in the Killing Floor series of zombie-slaying shooters.

The game was originally slated for release this month, but it now seems we'll have to wait a while before we learn exactly when it's coming. When it eventually does arrive, Killing Floor 3 will launch for PC, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series X|S.
